metadata.title: Torque Calculator
metadata.description: Calculate torque for engines, drivelines, and static loads with dyno-grade formulas, gear ratio effects, and SI/imperial outputs.

engine_torque_hp.label: Engine torque from horsepower and RPM
engine_torque_hp.description: Uses the 5252 relationship common to dynamometer work.

static_torque.label: Static torque from force and lever arm
static_torque.description: Moment about a pivot from perpendicular force application.

wheel_torque.label: Wheel torque from engine torque and gearing
wheel_torque.description: Propagates engine torque through gearbox, final drive, and driveline efficiency.

introduction: Quantify torque for engines, driveline setups, and static loads with lab-style transparency in both SI and imperial units.
Built for tuners, dyno operators, and test engineers who need traceable calculations tied to standards, gear ratios, and efficiency losses.
methodology: Engine torque follows the 5252 relationship linking horsepower and RPM; outputs are dual-reported in N·m and lb-ft for shop and lab contexts.
Static torque applies the moment arm relationship τ = F × r with unit-consistent conversion to lb-ft.
Wheel torque multiplies engine torque by gearbox and final drive ratios, then applies driveline efficiency to reflect measured losses.

faqs.question: How should I measure horsepower or torque for best accuracy?
faqs.answer: Use a calibrated chassis or engine dyno with recent NIST-traceable torque transducer calibration and stable intake temperature per ISO 1585 guidance.

faqs.question: What driveline efficiency should I use?
faqs.answer: Typical street drivetrains range 0.85–0.93; high-performance AWD with heavy oil shear can drop below 0.80. Use manufacturer data or coastdown tests when available.

faqs.question: Why do results differ from shop to shop?
faqs.answer: Variation comes from correction standards (SAE J1349 vs DIN 70020), ambient conditions, roller inertia, tire pressure, and whether torque is measured at the crank or wheels.
